awd_abstract_narration:
It is now possible to grow crystals from many different semiconductors that are just a few nanometers in size, or about 100,000 times smaller than a strand of hair.  At these very small sizes, semiconductor nanocrystals take on novel physical and chemical properties that can be adjusted by changing their size, shape, and chemical composition, making them attractive for use in many next-generation photonic and energy technologies.  Although they hold great promise, these nanocrystals also present unique challenges.  For example, as one charges a nanocrystal up by adding electrons, it can change color and new chemical reactions can take place at its surface.  With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Daniel Gamelin of the University of Washington is studying how electrons that are transferred into (and out of) semiconductor nanocrystals alter their physical properties and chemical reactivity. Working with his students, Professor Gamelin is developing new experimental methods that enable them to precisely alter the nanocrystal charge while monitoring changes in their physico-chemical properties. Their discoveries could have important implications for new technologies in energy conversion, energy storage, and efficient energy usage.  The project is also providing advanced interdisciplinary education and training for students, preparing them to be future leaders in science, engineering, technology innovation, and education. Integration of research and education is emphasized through involvement of undergraduates in the project, incorporation of project concepts into the UW undergraduate laboratory curriculum, and outreach activities at Seattle K-12 schools and community STEM events.

Despite extensive studies and progress in controlling the formation of high-quality colloidal reduced or oxidized semiconductor nanocrystals over recent years, the redox properties of colloidal nanocrystals remain poorly understood, particularly in the multiple-carrier regime relevant to charge-tunable plasmonics, high-density charge storage, or multi-electron catalysis. This project targets the development and application of new methods for measuring, controlling, and understanding the properties of redox-active colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals emphasizing spectroelectrochemical probes of nanoscale chemical transformations.  The goal is to elucidate the redox reactivities and associated physico-chemical properties of such nanocrystals that possess excess delocalized electrons or holes. Specific nanocrystal research foci include: metal-coupled electron-transfer reactions relevant to charge-tunable plasmonics,  soluble supercapacitors relevant to energy storage, and band-edge potentials of nanostructures relevant to photochemistry and electron transfer.  All of these are anticipated to play central roles in future nanocrystal technologies. Spectroelectrochemical potentiometry has been identified as a particularly powerful and quantitative probe of the redox properties of free-standing colloidal semiconductor NCs, and it is enabling unique in situ monitoring of nanocrystal redox manipulations and composition transformations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Washington Department of Chemistry

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

This project investigated the redox properties of colloidal inorganic nanocrystals using a combination of chemical, electrochemical, and spectroscopic approaches. The project used in situ potentiometry and spectroelectrochemistry to develop a fundamental understanding of ion-coupled electron-transfer reactions relevant to novel charge-storage technologies and potential new switchable plasmonics. The project applied potentiometric titration methods to probe the roles of composition, surface dipoles, surface trapping, and ligation on nanocrystal redox properties. The project applied a suite of spectroscopic tools to understand nanocrystal redox or catalytic reactivity, magnetism, and charge-storage functionality. The band-edge potentials and charge-storage capabilities of oxide and chalcogenide nanocrystals were probed by these methods, and inter-nanocrystal electron-transfer equilibria were investigated.

 

 

Intellectual merit. This project developed and applied a combination of synthesis and reactivity studies, spectroscopic measurements, electrochemical measurements, and other analytical experiments to elucidate fundamental structure/function relationships in redox-active colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals relevant to switchable plasmonics, energy storage, magnetic materials, and heterogeneous catalysis. The ability of aliovalent doping and surface ligation to tune the band-edge potentials of free-standing colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals was demonstrated. The effects of modulating surface charge state on magnetic nanocrystals were investigated, and the effects of introducing charged defects in oxide nanocrystals on their redox catalysis were also investigated. These studies led to advances in methodologies for preparing and studying redox-active colloidal inorganic nanocrystals and led to advances in fundamental knowledge about the factors influencing their redox properties as well as the impact of redox transformations on their other physical properties, such as magnetism. The new basic knowledge, materials, and technical capabilities generated from this project may ultimately accelerate the development of future technologies involving inorganic nanostructures.

 

 

Broader impact. This project has yielded new redox-active colloidal inorganic nanocrystals and new fundamental knowledge relevant to a wide variety of energy conversion, storage, and efficiency technologies, as well as to various sensing, catalysis, or photosensitization technologies. Characterization of the chemical reactivities, redox/electrochemical properties, spectroscopic properties, and electronic structures of inorganic nanocrystals has helped bridge the fields of nanocrystal chemistry, physics, analytical chemistry, and technology and has provided advanced interdisciplinary education and training opportunities for participating students and postdoctoral researchers. Participants collaborated with researchers on and off campus, and engaged in mature education, outreach, and professional-development programs at UW, preparing them for careers in science, engineering, and education. This project engaged multiple undergraduates, including visiting undergraduates from collaborating universities, providing them early career research opportunities and facilitating their advancement toward STEM higher education and professional employment. This project supported the PI's activities in organizing a regional conference for Pacific Northwest PUI and R1 students and researchers, as well as national laboratory and industry researchers also involved in nanoscience.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/11/2023
Modified by: Daniel R Gamelin
